comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: A famous stamp was issued in 1918 to commemorate this event: "1918 “Jenny” Airmail Stamp" by National Postal Museum From Edith Dodd Culver's THE DAY THE AIRMAIL BEGAN: "To quote from Reuben Fleet's 1966 speech before the Air Mail Pioneers: "I left Lieutenant Webb in charge at Belmont Park and the Curtiss plant, with Lieutenant Miller and Bonsal helping, and in reserve, and instructed Webb to get the other four aerial mail airplanes ready, and fly one from Belmont Park with the aerial mail at eleven the next morning to Bustleton Field, which the Philadelphia Postmaster had selected for Philadelphia. Edgerton at Bustleton Field would relieve Lieutenant Webb there and fly on to Washington, while Lieutenant Culver would relay the aerial mail at Busttleton Park in New York."

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: Lt. Torrey Webb flipped a Jenny airmail plane here: "Wrecked Airmail Plane" by Smithsonian

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: About a thousand spectators showed up at Bustleton to see Webb land. New York Times, May 16, 1918

comment.author: 111955182@N04
comment._content:
Great compilation.   Torrey is my second cousin twice removed.   I'd like my children to know about Torrey.
One of the stamps was auctioned recently for just short of a million dollars.... 
The commemorative stamp ($2 postal value) is available these days and collectors stamps are available on the USPS web site.
